div.head: Overview
div.p: The Sanskrit term dhāraṇī is difficult to translate into English using a single word that includes all its meanings. In different contexts it can refer to:

item.p: a supernormal generalized power of retention and memory developed mainly by bodhisattvas at certain stages of the path and seen as an important means of further progress;
one or many particular, named instructions or powers that allow access to certain realizations;
a set of syllables or words that similarly hold and transmit an instruction, but principally to confer protection;

an actual text (or the category of texts) centered on a dhāraṇī—in any of the above senses—that typically also contains additional material such as an introductory narrative, instructions for its use, and details of its benefits.

div.p: The notion of dhāraṇī as an essential element of the path is widespread in Buddhist traditions, and dhāraṇī texts—especially protective ones—have played an important part in Buddhist practice and popular belief. particularly in the Mahāyāna. It is by no means confined to tantric traditions, despite certain parallels with tantric uses of mantra.

The Kangyur contains a large number of dhāraṇī texts, some classified as sūtra but many placed in the category of Action (kriyā) Tantra, even though some of these are not obviously tantric in nature. Kangyurs of the Tshalpa group mostly include a section of largely duplicated dhāraṇī texts as a separate Compendium of Dhāraṇīs.

div.head: Etymology and Usage
div.p: The Buddhist spiritual path is an explicitly long-term undertaking, and for a teaching to be put into practice and subsequently made available to others, clear and accurate memory, retention over long periods, and verifiable transmission are all of obvious importance.

The Sanskrit term dhāraṇī is derived from the Sanskrit root √dhṛ (“to hold” or “to maintain”), and among its wide range of meanings most are closely related to the retaining—in the mind or awareness, in the memory, in spoken words, or in writing—of a particular teaching, realization, or approach to awakening. The “holding” of dhāraṇī in most senses seems to refer more to what it is that holds than to what is held, although the distinction is not always a clear one.

Although dhāraṇī is sometimes compared to forms of mnemonic technique, the way a dhāraṇī holds (or provides access to) content beyond itself seems to rely not so much on arbitrary associations functioning as cues as on the kind of relationships that link a general or abstract principle to its specific or actual applications.

Perhaps because the notion of dhāraṇī was widely accepted and understood, a fully informative, systematic explanation of exactly what dhāraṇī is does not seem to be found in the sūtras themselves. Passages about dhāraṇī within the sūtras nevertheless yield helpful information, and the material they contain can be classified according to the principal sense of the term that, among the range of such senses, is the most relevant in each case. Further perspectives can be found in explanations in the treatises; these remain to be fully explored. In the following breakdown of some of the senses that can be distinguished from the texts, it should be emphasized that there is a great deal of overlap. While usage and aspect vary, the underlying meaning remains constant.

div.head: A. Dhāraṇī as a generic power that is accomplished
div.p: In many sūtras whose introductory setting describes the attendance of bodhisattvas in some detail, the list of their qualities and accomplishments often mention that they have “attained dhāraṇī” (translated in some cases in this context as “retention”). Some examples among many such instances are:

item.p: The Questions of the Girl Vimalaśraddhā (Dārikāvimalaśraddhāparipṛcchā, Toh 84)
Teaching the Practice of a Bodhisattva (Bodhisattva­caryānirdeśa, Toh 184)
The Absorption of the Thus-Gone One’s Wisdom Seal (Tathāgata­jñāna­mudrā­samādhi, Toh 131)

div.p: In contexts of this kind, dhāraṇī (or retention) seems to refer to an accomplishment by bodhisattvas of a supernormal power—a generic one in these instances—to remember, retain, recall, retrieve, and reproduce teachings they have heard and realized. As a description in The Absorption That Encapsulates All Merit (Sarvapuṇya­samuccaya­samādhi, Toh 134, at ) puts it, “They have no forgetting, and thus achieve retention.”

Dhāraṇī is often associated closely in such lists with inspired eloquence (pratibhāna), which reinforces the notion that it plays an important role in ensuring that a bodhisattva has access to vast resources of teaching. It may also be linked to absorption or absorptions (samādhi) and other qualities, as mentioned below (see ).

A stanza that could serve as a description of dhāraṇī in this sense of a generalized power is found in The Questions of Rāṣṭrapāla (1) (Rāṣṭrapāla­paripṛcchā, Toh 62) , where dhāraṇī (here “retention”) is listed as the first of four influences that inspire bodhisattvas (along with the spiritual friend, receptiveness to the profond Dharma, and discipline), and is described as follows:

lg.l: Those of great renown possess retention,
By which they behold the supreme Dharma that all buddhas have proclaimed.
Because they never lose it, their intellect increases.
They possess wisdom, lack attachment, and have mastered all qualities. {54}

div.p: However, the overall simplicity of this description, at least in the first two lines, cannot necessarily be taken as definitive. Additional qualities, like those that in the last two lines of this description are set out as consequences of possessing dhāraṇī, are in other texts simply included aas elements of dhāraṇī as a power attained by bodhisattvas. In Eliminating Ajātaśatru’s Remorse (Ajāta­śatru­kaukṛtya­vinodana, Toh 216) starting at , Mañjuśrī gives a detailed (and instructive) teaching on dhāraṇī that begins:

q.p: “In this regard, what is dhāraṇī? Dhāraṇī refers to unfailing recollection; unwavering understanding; undeluded intelligence; clear knowledge; knowing how to teach the path by demonstrating suchness in all phenomena; maintining the result once it is attained; knowing how to enter the path of maturity; knowing how to differentiate the words for all phenomena; continuing the family of noble ones by means of dhāraṇī; upholding the family of the buddhas; consolidating the family of Dharma; knowing the family of the saṅgha to be in accord with the Dharma; being undeluded about questions and teachings; not being timid before any retinue; …”

div.p: and continues to add further seemingly diverse aspects, including the ability to speak different languages, ability to take on the sufferings of beings, detachment, insatiable energy and dedication, and more. A quite similar but even more detailed description is given in The Secrets of the Realized Ones (Tathāgataguhya, Toh 47), et seq.

But if memory, even given this whole range of various other qualities, remains the key element of dhāraṇī, it is made clear that the kind of memory implied by the term dhāraṇī is not simply an extension of ordinary human memory, even memory developed to a prodigious degree. In The Jewel Cloud (Ratnamegha, Toh 231) dhāraṇī is listed as the eighth of ten qualities of bodhisattvas who possess excellent power and is described as follows at :

q.p: “What, you may wonder, does the bodhisattvas’ excellent power of retention consist in? In a single instant, bodhisattvas are able to recollect, comprehend, and apply each distinct meaning, word, expression, and way of teaching contained in all the Dharma discourses delivered by as many buddhas as there are in an inexpressible number of inexpressibly many buddha realms. Such is the bodhisattvas’ excellent power of retention.”

div.head: i) Grouped dhāraṇīs with names
div.p: In other sūtras, dhāraṇīs are given individual specificity by being named. Several—often numerous—named dhāraṇīs may be mentioned. For example, in The Teaching on the Great Compassion of the Tathāgata (Tathāgata­mahā­karuṇā­nirdeśa, Toh 147) at , Dhāraṇīśvararāja lists eight bodhisattva dhāraṇīs:

q.p: “Son of noble family, when bodhisattvas are established in dhāraṇīs, they retain all that the blessed buddhas say, and when they teach the Dharma it becomes inexhaustible. Since they explain it carefully, they satisfy all beings. The bodhisattva dhāraṇīs are eight: the (1) pure melody dhāraṇī, (2) inexhaustible basket dhāraṇī, (3) limitless enfoldment dhāraṇī, (4) ocean mudrā dhāraṇī, (5) lotus array dhāraṇī, (6) entering the gate of nonattachment dhāraṇī, (7) entering ascertainment by discriminating knowledge dhāraṇī, and (8) blessing of the buddha ornaments dhāraṇī.”

div.p:
The sūtra goes on to describe each of these eight in some detail. In this particular case, the eight dhāraṇīs described in this text are listed among the twelve named dhāraṇīs included in the Mahāvyutpatti (no. 748). Similar listings are found in the
Ratnamegha
(Toh 231) and the
Tathāgata­guṇa­jñānācintya­viṣayāvatāra­nirdeśa
(Toh 185).For an informative discussion of these, see Pagel (2007a), pp. 151–91.
In other cases, the names are not systematically matched by mentions in other works. In The Ten Bhūmis (Daśabhūmika, chapter 31 of the Avataṃsaka, Toh 44) at :

q.p: “O jinaputras! The bodhisattva who is skilled in having that wisdom of discerning knowledge has attained the ninth bodhisattva bhūmi, has obtained the treasure of the Dharma of tathāgatas, and has become a great dharmabhāṇaka. At that time he attains the dhāraṇī of meaning. He attains the dhāraṇī of the Dharma. He attains the dhāraṇī of the accomplishment of wisdom. He attains the dhāraṇī of radiance. He attains the dhāraṇī of perfect understanding, the dhāraṇī of wealth, the dhāraṇī of fame, the dhāraṇī of majesty, the dhāraṇī of unimpeded doors, the dhāraṇī of the infinite, and the dhāraṇī of a treasury of various meanings. He has attained the completion of those and other dhāraṇīs, countless millions of dhāraṇī doors. He is skilled in the aspects of speech through possessing countless millions of dhāraṇī doors, and he therefore teaches the Dharma through incalculable doors of different kinds of eloquence.”

“Because of those incalculable, countless millions of dhāraṇīs, when he hears the Dharma from countless buddhas in the ten directions, he does not forget what he has heard. He then gives countless different teachings that he has heard. Because of these millions of dhāraṇī doors he masters the Dharma he receives from one buddha. Just as he does with one buddha, he masters the Dharma from infinite buddhas because of those millions of dhāraṇī doors. Simply through wishing for it, he receives the radiance of even more Dharma doors from the samyak­sambuddhas. This cannot be accomplished by a śrāvaka, even though he has attained a great stage of hearing many teachings, has attained the retention of remembering what he has heard, and has been empowered to possess it for hundreds of thousands of eons.”

div.head: ii) Single dhāraṇīs with names
div.p:
A few sūtras focus primarily on a single, named dhāraṇī of this kind. The dhāraṇī expounded in them seems to retain its specificity, yet at the same time may be described as the source or entrance for a complete set of elements of the path, or even the whole of the Dharma. Examples of this genre are
The Dhāraṇī “Entering into Nonconceptuality”
(Avikalpapraveśadhāraṇī, Toh 142) and
The Dhāraṇī of the Jewel Torch
(Ratnolkādhāraṇī, Toh 145). The former text does not include an actual dhāraṇī formula as described below, while the latter does. Nevertheless, the main point in both is that the teaching given by the Buddha is described at length in terms other than simply being a verbal formula.

Another example in the same category is
The Absorption of the Thus-Gone One’s Wisdom Seal
(Tathāgata­jñāna­mudrā­samādhi, Toh 131), with the interesting difference that in this text it is an absorption (samādhi)—the one named in the title—that is described secondarily and variously as a dhāraṇī, as a dhāraṇī gateway, and as leading to dhāraṇī.

div.head: C. Specific dhāraṇīs as a group comprising one of a range of categories
div.p: In many sūtras, dhāraṇī is one among several closely related categories that seem to classify doctrines or realizations into grouped “units” that share similar functions (but whose apparently distinct natures are not easy to discern). Some have already been mentioned in the context of bodhisattva accomplishments (see above). Among these are

item.p: gateways, doors, or entrances (mukha or praveśa)

div.head: D. Specific dhāraṇīs in relation to letters
E. Dhāraṇīs that are verbal formulae
F. Dhāraṇīs that are texts containing verbal formulae
II. In the Treatises
div.p: One of the most complete explanations is found in Asaṅga’s Bodhisattvabhūmi:

q.p: Regarding this [topic), what are the bodhisattvas' forms of [mental] retention?'119 In brief, they should be regarded as being of four types: (1) retention of the Dharma, (2) retention of meaning, (3) retention by means of spells, and (4) the retention that is directed toward attainment of a bodhisattva's forbearance. Regarding this [topic), what is retention of the Dharma? Here a bodhisattva attains a development of power"20 consisting of wisdom and recollection such that by means of it he or she can retain [in the mind] for an immeasurable period of time immeasurable numbers of scriptures containing collections of words, assertions, and syllables that were not committed to memory and were not recited aloud, in the order that they were created and in the order that they were arranged, merely by having listened to them. Regarding this [topic), what is retention of meaning? The description] is the same as before, but in this case there is this differ-ence. [A bodhisattva] retains [in the mind] for an immeasurable period of time immeasurable numbers of meanings relating to the very same Dharma teachings [contained in those scriptures, without having committed them to memory and without having reviewed them in the mind. Regarding this topic, what is retention by means of spells? Here a bodhisattva attains a power of one-pointed concentration such that by means of it those mantra spells that [have the potential to] spiritually influence beings and cure their infectious diseases are rendered effective, supremely effective, and unfailing [in their ability] to cure many different kinds of infectious diseases. This [quality] is called a bodhisattva's "reten-tion by means of spells." Regarding this topic, what is a bodhisattva's [form of mental] retention that is directed toward attainment of a bodhisattva's forbearance? 6. Here a bodhisattva who has him- or herself practiced the causes fully, 1122 who is possessed of wisdom, lives in solitude, who neither utters speech nor comes within the sight of anyone else, who likewise eats in moderation, does not eat in a haphazard manner, 123 and eats only one kind of food,1124 who is dedicated to meditation, sleeps only a little at night, and maintains a high degree of alertness contemplates, ponders, and examines the meaning of those mantra spells that the Tathagata uttered for the sake of attaining forbearance, such as the one which states): iti miti kiti bhiksanti padani sva hà"S Having correctly undertaken the practice of] these mantra spells and without having heard their meaning from anyone else, he or she realizes it in the following manner: "There is no realization of the meaning of these mantra spells. They do not contain any meaning. Their meaning is that they have no meaning." Following that, he or she does not seek any further meaning. In this way, he or she gains a correct realization of the meanings of these mantra spells. 7. Having gained a correct realization of the meanings of these mantra spells, he or she then gains a correct realization of the meanings of all entities that conforms with that very understanding of the mantra spells]. Without having heard (the meaning of all entities] from anyone else, he or she realizes it in the following manner: "No meaning that pertains to a [real] essence can be established by means of any expressions in relation to any entity. 8. This ineffable essential nature is the meaning that represents their essential nature." After he or she has correctly realized the meaning that represents the essential nature of all entities in this way, [a bodhisattva] does not seek any other meaning. Through having gained a realization of that meaning, he or she attains a joyful rapture. What a bodhisattva attains on the strength of these mantra spells is called a "forbearance." Through having gained that [forbearance], a bodhisattva will before long attain the pur🎛🎛🎛🎛🎛🎛 his or her superior attitude. He or she has advanced to the great form of forbearance that occurs on the stage in which conduct is based upon devorion. This should be understood as the [form of mental] retention that is directed toward the attainment of a bodhisattva's forbearance. Regarding this (topic], after having gone beyond the first span of time that is made up of countless kalpas," a bodhisattva who has entered the stage of a pure superior attitude"7 attains forms of the retention of the Dharma and the retention of meanings that are sure, firm, and exalted. Prior to that time, they are attained on the strength of aspirational prayers or on the basis of meditative absorptions, but they are not sure, firm, or exalted. As with the retentions of the Dharma and meanings, the same should be understood as being true for the retention by means of spells. However, the retention that is directed toward the attainment of a bodhisattva's forbear-ance is only attained in the manner that was just described. Furthermore, a bodhisattva will artain all of these [forms of] retention if he or she possesses four qualities; he or she will not do so if any one of them is missing. What are the four qualities? (r) He or she does not have attachment for sensory pleasures. (2) He or she does nor develop envy toward those who have attained an elevated status and he or she remains free of envy. (3) He or she is one who gives everything that is requested of him or her and is not a giver who regrets [acts of generos-ity] afterward. (4) He or she takes pleasure in the Dharma and is devoted to the Dharma that relates to the bodhisattva collection [of scriptures] or to the manuals for that collection.
